prompts: In linguistics , an internationalism or international word is a loanword that
baseline: In linguistics, an internationalism or international word is a loanword that occurs in several languages (that is, translingually) with the same or at least similar meaning and etymology.

prompts: It is debated how many languages are required for a word
baseline: It is debated how many languages are required for a word to be considered an internationalism.

prompts: For example , according to Ghil'ad Zuckermann , the most important languages that should include the same lexical
baseline: For example, according to Ghil'ad Zuckermann, the most important languages that should include the same lexical item in order for it to qualify as an internationalism in Hebrew are Yiddish, Polish, Russian, French, German and English.

prompts: Internationalism is a political principle that advocates greater political or
baseline: Internationalism is a political principle that advocates greater political or economic cooperation among states and nations.

prompts: Supporters of internationalism are known as internationalists and generally believe that humans should
baseline: Supporters of internationalism are known as internationalists and generally believe that humans should unite across national, political, cultural, racial, or class boundaries to advance their common interests, or that governments should cooperate because their mutual long-term interests are of greater importance than their short-term disputes.

prompts: Internationalism has several interpretations and meanings , but is usually characterized by opposition to
baseline: Internationalism has several interpretations and meanings, but is usually characterized by opposition to ultranationalism and isolationism; support for international institutions, such as the United Nations, and a cosmopolitan outlook that promotes and respects other cultures and customs.

prompts: Cobden and Bright were against the protectionist Corn Laws and in a speech at Covent Garden on September 28 , 1843 , Cobden outlined his utopian brand
baseline: Cobden and Bright were against the protectionist Corn Laws and in a speech at Covent Garden on September 28, 1843, Cobden outlined his utopian brand of internationalism:

prompts: A belief in the idea of the moral law and an inherent goodness in human nature also inspired their faith in
baseline: A belief in the idea of the moral law and an inherent goodness in human nature also inspired their faith in internationalism.

prompts: Those liberal conceptions of internationalism were harshly criticized by socialists and
baseline: Those liberal conceptions of internationalism were harshly criticized by socialists and radicals at the time, who pointed out the links between global economic competition and imperialism, and would identify this competition as being a root cause of world conflict.

prompts: Referred to as the First International , the organization was dedicated to the advancement
baseline: Referred to as the First International, the organization was dedicated to the advancement of working class political interests across national boundaries, and was in direct ideological opposition to strains of liberal internationalism which advocated free trade and capitalism as means of achieving world peace and interdependence.

prompts: The flag of the United
baseline: The flag of the United Nations, the world's premier international organization and proponent of internationalism

prompts: Ramsay MacDonald , a political
baseline: Ramsay MacDonald, a political spokesman for internationalism

prompts: Internationalism expressed itself in Britain
baseline: Internationalism expressed itself in Britain through the endorsement of the League of Nations by such people as Gilbert Murray.

prompts: Internationalism is most commonly expressed as an appreciation
baseline: Internationalism is most commonly expressed as an appreciation for the diverse cultures in the world, and a desire for world peace.

prompts: Contributors to the current version of internationalism include Albert Einstein ,
baseline: Contributors to the current version of internationalism include Albert Einstein, who was a socialist and believed in a world government, and classified the follies of nationalism as "an infantile sickness".

prompts: Such a view , such global consciousness , may be termed internationalism , the
baseline: Such a view, such global consciousness, may be termed internationalism, the idea that nations and peoples should cooperate instead of preoccupying themselves with their respective national interests or pursuing uncoordinated approaches to promote them.

prompts: In the strict meaning of the word , internationalism is still based on the existence
baseline: In the strict meaning of the word, internationalism is still based on the existence of sovereign state.

prompts: Internationalism is an important component of socialist political theory , based on the principle
baseline: Internationalism is an important component of socialist political theory, based on the principle that working-class people of all countries must unite across national boundaries and actively oppose nationalism and war in order to overthrow capitalism.

prompts: In this sense , the socialist understanding of internationalism is closely related to the concept
baseline: In this sense, the socialist understanding of internationalism is closely related to the concept of international solidarity.

prompts: Socialist internationalism is anti - imperialist , and therefore supports the liberation of
baseline: Socialist internationalism is anti-imperialist, and therefore supports the liberation of peoples from all forms of colonialism and foreign domination, and the right of nations to self-determination.

prompts: It was an association of communist political parties from throughout the world dedicated to proletarian internationalism
baseline: It was an association of communist political parties from throughout the world dedicated to proletarian internationalism and the revolutionary overthrow of the world bourgeoisie.

prompts: The Fourth International declared itself to be the true ideological successor of the original Comintern under Lenin , carrying on the banner
baseline: The Fourth International declared itself to be the true ideological successor of the original Comintern under Lenin, carrying on the banner of proletarian internationalism which had been abandoned by Stalin's Comintern.

prompts: In his work Banal Nationalism , critic Michael Billig argued internationalism was borne
baseline: In his work Banal Nationalism, critic Michael Billig argued internationalism was borne out of the rise of nationalism, and rejects attempts to counterpose the two.

prompts: He writes : " An outward - looking element of internationalism
baseline: He writes: "An outward-looking element of internationalism is part of nationalism and has accompanied the rise of nationalism historically.

prompts: When US presidents , today , claim to speak simultaneously
baseline: When US presidents, today, claim to speak simultaneously on behalf of their nation and a new world order, they are not placing, side by side in the same utterance, elements from two, clearly separate ideologies; nor are they creating a novel synthesis from the thesis of nationalism and the antithesis of internationalism.

prompts: Through Derrida 's use of Hamlet , he shows the influence that
baseline: Through Derrida's use of Hamlet, he shows the influence that Shakespeare had on Marx and Engel's work on internationalism.

prompts: Proletarian internationalism was strongly embraced by the first communist party , the Communist League , as exercised through its slogan
baseline: Proletarian internationalism was strongly embraced by the first communist party, the Communist League, as exercised through its slogan "Proletarians of all countries, unite!", later popularized as "Workers of the world, unite!" in English literature.

prompts: After the formation of the Soviet Union , Marxist proponents of internationalism suggested that country could
baseline: After the formation of the Soviet Union, Marxist proponents of internationalism suggested that country could be used as a "homeland of communism" from which revolution could be spread around the globe.

prompts: Proponents of proletarian internationalism often argued that the objectives of a given revolution should be
baseline: Proponents of proletarian internationalism often argued that the objectives of a given revolution should be global rather than local in scope—for example, triggering or perpetuating revolutions elsewhere.

prompts: Proletarian internationalism is closely linked to goals of world revolution , to be achieved through successive or
baseline: Proletarian internationalism is closely linked to goals of world revolution, to be achieved through successive or simultaneous communist revolutions in all nations.

prompts: According to Marxist theory , successful proletarian internationalism should lead to world communism
baseline: According to Marxist theory, successful proletarian internationalism should lead to world communism and eventually stateless communism.

prompts: Proletarian internationalism is summed up in the slogan coined by Karl Marx
baseline: Proletarian internationalism is summed up in the slogan coined by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, "Workers of the world, unite!", the last line of The Communist Manifesto, published in 1848.

prompts: Proletarian internationalism was perhaps best expressed in the resolution sponsored by Vladimir Lenin
baseline: Proletarian internationalism was perhaps best expressed in the resolution sponsored by Vladimir Lenin and Rosa Luxemburg at the Seventh Congress of the Second International at Stuttgart in 1907 which asserted:

prompts: However , once this revolutionary wave had receded in the early
baseline: However, once this revolutionary wave had receded in the early 1920s, proletarian internationalism was no longer mainstream in working class politics.

prompts: Trotsky 's biographer , Isaac Deutscher , has explicitly contrasted his support for
baseline: Trotsky's biographer, Isaac Deutscher, has explicitly contrasted his support for proletarian internationalism against his opposition to revolution by military conquest as seen with his documented opposition to the war with Poland in 1920, proposed armistice with the Entente and temperance with staging anti-British revolts in the Middle East.

prompts: The Soviet government defined its relationship with Eastern European states it occupied such as Bulgaria
baseline: The Soviet government defined its relationship with Eastern European states it occupied such as Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary as based on the principles of proletarian internationalism.

prompts: Communist ideologues believed that proletarian internationalism was no longer accurate to describe Soviet relations with
baseline: Communist ideologues believed that proletarian internationalism was no longer accurate to describe Soviet relations with the newly emerging Eastern European communist bloc, so a new term was coined, namely socialist internationalism.

prompts: According to Soviet internationalist theory under Nikita Khrushchev , proletarian internationalism could only be evoked to describe solidarity
baseline: According to Soviet internationalist theory under Nikita Khrushchev, proletarian internationalism could only be evoked to describe solidarity between international peoples and parties, not governments.

prompts: Inter - state relationships fell into a parallel
baseline: Inter-state relationships fell into a parallel category, socialist internationalism.

prompts: Socialist internationalism was considerably less militant than proletarian internationalism as it was not focused on the spread
baseline: Socialist internationalism was considerably less militant than proletarian internationalism as it was not focused on the spread of revolution, but diplomatic, political and to a lesser extent cultural solidarity between preexisting regimes.

prompts: Under the principles of socialist internationalism , the Warsaw Pact governments were encouraged to pursue various
baseline: Under the principles of socialist internationalism, the Warsaw Pact governments were encouraged to pursue various forms of economic or military cooperation with each other and Moscow.

prompts: At the Moscow International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties in June 1969 , seventy - five communist parties from around the world formally defined and endorsed the
baseline: At the Moscow International Meeting of Communist and Workers Parties in June 1969, seventy-five communist parties from around the world formally defined and endorsed the theory of socialist internationalism.

prompts: One of the key tenets of socialist internationalism as expressed during the conference
baseline: One of the key tenets of socialist internationalism as expressed during the conference was that the "defense of socialism is the international duty of communists", meaning communist governments should be obliged to assist each other militarily to defend their common interests against external aggression.

prompts: Khrushchev 's successor , Leonid Brezhnev , was an even more
baseline: Khrushchev's successor, Leonid Brezhnev, was an even more outspoken proponent of both proletarian and socialist internationalism.

prompts: In 1976 , Brezhnev declared that proletarian internationalism was neither dead nor obsolete and reaffirmed the Soviet Union
baseline: In 1976, Brezhnev declared that proletarian internationalism was neither dead nor obsolete and reaffirmed the Soviet Union's commitment to its core concepts of "the solidarity of the working class, of communists of all countries in the struggle for common goals, the solidarity in the struggle of the peoples for national liberation and social progress,  voluntary cooperation of the fraternal parties with strict observance of the equality and independence of each".

prompts: Under Brezhnev , the Soviet and Warsaw Pact governments frequently evoked proletarian internationalism to
baseline: Under Brezhnev, the Soviet and Warsaw Pact governments frequently evoked proletarian internationalism to fund leftist trade unions and guerrilla insurgencies around the globe.

prompts: Outside of the Warsaw Pact , Cuba embraced its own aggressive
baseline: Outside of the Warsaw Pact, Cuba embraced its own aggressive theory of proletarian internationalism, which was primarily exercised through support for leftist revolutionary movements.

prompts: One of the fundamental aspects of Cuban foreign policy between 1962 and 1990 was the " rule
baseline: One of the fundamental aspects of Cuban foreign policy between 1962 and 1990 was the "rule of internationalism", which dictated that Cuba must first and foremost support the cause of international revolution through whatever means are available to her.

prompts: Communist Party of the Philippines theorist and activist Jose Maria Sison writes that while every
baseline: Communist Party of the Philippines theorist and activist Jose Maria Sison writes that while every proletarian party and state must be guided by proletarian internationalism, “this does not mean that revolution can be imported or exported from one country to another.

prompts: Some political groupings such as the International Communist Party , the International Communist Current and the Internationalist Communist Tendency ( formerly the International Bureau for the Revolutionary Party , which includes the PCInt ) follow the Luxemburgist and
baseline: Some political groupings such as the International Communist Party, the International Communist Current and the Internationalist Communist Tendency (formerly the International Bureau for the Revolutionary Party, which includes the PCInt) follow the Luxemburgist and Bordigist interpretations of proletarian internationalism as do some libertarian communists.

prompts: In contrast , some socialists have pointed out that social
baseline: In contrast, some socialists have pointed out that social realities such as local loyalties and cultural barriers militate against proletarian internationalism.

prompts: Marxists would also point out that in times of intense revolutionary struggle ( the most evident being the revolutionary periods of 1848 , 1917–1923 and 1968 ) internationalism within the proletariat can overtake petty nationalisms as
baseline: Marxists would also point out that in times of intense revolutionary struggle (the most evident being the revolutionary periods of 1848, 1917–1923 and 1968) internationalism within the proletariat can overtake petty nationalisms as intense class struggles break out in multiple nations at the same time and the workers of those nations discover that they have more in common with other workers than with their own bourgeoisie.

prompts: On the question of imperialism and national determination , proponents of Third - Worldism argue that workers in
baseline: On the question of imperialism and national determination, proponents of Third-Worldism argue that workers in "oppressor" nations (such as the United States or Israel) must first support national liberation movements in "oppressed" nations (such as Afghanistan or Palestine) before there can be any basis for proletarian internationalism.
